body.p:
Covington Mch 30 1864
His Excellency
Gov Thos E Bramlette
Frankfort Ky
Sir

At the December Term of the Kenton Circuit Court two inditments against George Oakes were tried and and he found guilty and fined by a jury in one case $60 and the other $200 One of the indictments was for keeping a tippling house and the other was for suffering gaming. The proof in the first case was that defd had a little Shanty and was cutting wood and selling it &c

and that he had sold whiskey twice and suffered it to be drunk on the premises In the second case the proof was that a party of men had played poker in the Cabin in the woods of Oakes five cents ante. The Defendant is a very poor & ^ignorant^ man and unable to pay this fine. indeed he cannot pay. If he pays the costs it will be as much as I think he can do I have written this at the request Messrs Hamilton & Carlisle who have taken some interest in this man. On a/c of the extreme poverty of the defendant I think this a proper case for execution interposition
and mercy

Very truly your
obt servt
R B Carpenter
Comths atty
